levels.label: entry
levels.description: Reading and writing numbers to 100,000 using a place value chart with columns labelled TTh, Th, H, T, O.
levels.example_task: Place digit cards on the place value chart to make 47,302. What is the value of the 7?
levels.example_response: 47,302. The 7 is worth 7,000 (seven thousand).
common_errors: Saying the 7 is worth 700 (placing it in the hundreds column mentally)
Writing 47,302 without the comma and misreading it as 4,732

levels.label: developing
levels.description: Reading, writing and ordering numbers to 1,000,000, including numbers with zero placeholders in multiple columns.
levels.example_task: Write in digits: three hundred and four thousand and fifty-six. Order these: 456,000; 465,000; 405,600; 450,600.
common_errors: Writing 304,056 as 30,456 (omitting the zero placeholder in the thousands)
Ordering by looking at the last three digits rather than comparing from the left

levels.label: expected
levels.description: Identifying the value of any digit in a number up to 1,000,000, partitioning flexibly, and comparing and ordering such numbers fluently.
levels.example_task: What is the value of the 6 in 862,415? Partition 750,000 in three different ways.
common_errors: Saying the 6 is worth 6,000 (misidentifying the column)
Only knowing the standard partition and being unable to partition flexibly

levels.label: greater_depth
levels.description: Explaining the multiplicative structure of the place value system: each column is 10 times the one to its right, and using this to reason about equivalences.
levels.example_task: Explain why 400,000 is the same as 4,000 hundreds. How many tens are there in 1,000,000?
common_errors: Computing 1,000,000 ÷ 10 as 10,000 instead of 100,000
Being unable to explain the multiplicative relationship between non-adjacent columns

levels.label: entry
levels.description: Rounding numbers to the nearest 10, 100 and 1,000 (consolidating Year 4 skills with larger numbers).
levels.example_task: Round 34,567 to the nearest 1,000.
levels.example_response: 35,000. The hundreds digit is 5, so round up.
common_errors: Looking at the tens digit instead of the hundreds digit when rounding to the nearest 1,000
Rounding to 34,000 (rounding down when the deciding digit is 5)

levels.label: developing
levels.description: Rounding to the nearest 10,000 and 100,000 using a number line to identify the bounding multiples.
levels.example_task: Round 347,500 to the nearest 100,000. Round 347,500 to the nearest 10,000.
levels.example_response: To nearest 100,000: 300,000 (4 < 5, round down). To nearest 10,000: 350,000 (7 ≥ 5, round up).
common_errors: Rounding 347,500 to the nearest 100,000 as 400,000 (looking at the wrong digit)
Confusing which digit to examine for each level of rounding

levels.label: expected
levels.description: Rounding any number up to 1,000,000 to any specified degree of accuracy, and using rounding for estimation.
levels.example_task: Estimate 47,832 × 6 by rounding to the nearest 10,000 first.
common_errors: Rounding both numbers when only one needs rounding
Not using the estimate to check the reasonableness of the exact answer

levels.label: entry
levels.description: Identifying whether numbers up to 20 are prime or not by listing their factors.
levels.example_task: List the factors of 12. Is 12 prime? List the factors of 13. Is 13 prime?
levels.example_response: Factors of 12: 1, 2, 3, 4, 6, 12 — not prime (more than 2 factors). Factors of 13: 1, 13 — prime (exactly 2 factors).
common_errors: Including 1 as a prime number (it has only one factor, not two)
Forgetting to check all possible factors (missing 3 as a factor of 12)

levels.label: developing
levels.description: Using the Sieve of Eratosthenes to identify prime numbers up to 50, and knowing that 2 is the only even prime.
levels.example_task: Is 2 prime? Why is it the only even prime number?
levels.example_response: Yes, 2 is prime — its only factors are 1 and 2. It is the only even prime because every other even number has 2 as a factor (in addition to 1 and itself), giving it more than 2 factors.
common_errors: Saying 2 is not prime because 'all primes are odd'
Not understanding why all even numbers greater than 2 are composite

levels.label: expected
levels.description: Identifying whether any number up to 100 is prime, recalling primes up to 19, and explaining why 1 is not prime.
levels.example_task: Is 51 prime? Explain your method. Why is 1 not a prime number?
levels.example_response: 51 is not prime: 51 = 3 × 17. I checked divisibility by 2 (no — it's odd), then 3 (5+1=6, divisible by 3). 1 is not prime because it has only one factor (1 itself), and primes must have exactly two factors.
common_errors: Saying 51 is prime because it looks odd and doesn't end in 0 or 5
Explaining that 1 is 'too small' to be prime rather than giving the correct definition

levels.label: entry
levels.description: Building square numbers using arrays of counters and recognising the pattern: 1, 4, 9, 16, 25.
levels.example_task: Make a 4 × 4 square from counters. How many counters? Write this using the ² notation.
levels.example_response: 16 counters. 4² = 16. It is called '4 squared' because it makes a square array.
common_errors: Writing 4² = 8 (multiplying by 2 instead of squaring)
Not connecting the physical square shape to the notation n²

levels.label: developing
levels.description: Recalling square numbers up to 12² = 144 and the first five cube numbers, using the notation n² and n³.
levels.example_task: What is 7²? What is 3³?
common_errors: Computing 7² as 14 (7 × 2 instead of 7 × 7)
Computing 3³ as 9 (3 × 3 instead of 3 × 3 × 3)

levels.label: expected
levels.description: Using square and cube numbers in context, connecting to area and volume, and identifying numbers as square or cube.
levels.example_task: A square has area 64 cm². What is its side length? Is 64 also a cube number?
levels.example_response: Side length = 8 cm because 8² = 64. 64 is also a cube number: 4³ = 64.
common_errors: Not connecting area of a square to square numbers (trying to divide 64 by 4 instead of finding the square root)
Not knowing that 64 is both a square number (8²) and a cube number (4³)

levels.label: entry
levels.description: Finding all factor pairs of numbers up to 30 by systematic trial.
levels.example_task: Find all the factor pairs of 24.
common_errors: Stopping after finding (1,24) and (2,12) and missing (3,8) and (4,6)
Listing multiples of 24 instead of factors

levels.label: developing
levels.description: Finding common factors and common multiples of two numbers using Venn diagrams.
levels.example_task: Find the common factors of 18 and 24. What is the highest common factor?
levels.example_response: Factors of 18: 1, 2, 3, 6, 9, 18. Factors of 24: 1, 2, 3, 4, 6, 8, 12, 24. Common factors: 1, 2, 3, 6. HCF = 6.
common_errors: Including factors of one number that are not factors of the other in the common list
Finding only one common factor and stopping

levels.label: expected
levels.description: Finding HCF and LCM, and applying them to simplify fractions and find common denominators.
levels.example_task: Simplify 18/24 using the HCF. Find the LCM of 4 and 6.
levels.example_response: HCF of 18 and 24 is 6. 18/24 = 3/4. LCM of 4 and 6: multiples of 4 are 4, 8, 12, 16...; multiples of 6 are 6, 12, 18... LCM = 12.
common_errors: Dividing only the numerator by the HCF (getting 3/24 instead of 3/4)
Confusing HCF and LCM (using the LCM to simplify or the HCF to find common denominators)

levels.label: entry
levels.description: Multiplying a two-digit number by a two-digit number using the grid method as a bridge to the formal layout.
levels.example_task: Use the grid method to work out 34 × 23.
common_errors: Missing one of the four partial products in the grid
Adding the partial products incorrectly

levels.label: developing
levels.description: Using the formal long multiplication layout for up to 3-digit × 2-digit, with the zero placeholder in the second row.
levels.example_task: Use long multiplication: 156 × 27.
common_errors: Forgetting the zero placeholder in the second row (writing 312 instead of 3,120)
Carrying errors in the first or second row

levels.label: expected
levels.description: Reliably computing any up-to 4-digit × 2-digit multiplication using long multiplication, with estimation to check.
levels.example_task: Estimate, then calculate: 2,345 × 46.
common_errors: Misaligning the second partial product row
Not estimating first and therefore not catching errors (e.g. getting 10,787 instead of 107,870)

levels.label: entry
levels.description: Dividing a two-digit number by a one-digit number using the short division ('bus stop') layout with no remainders.
levels.example_task: Use short division: 84 ÷ 4.
levels.example_response: 8 ÷ 4 = 2 (write 2 above the 8). 4 ÷ 4 = 1 (write 1 above the 4). Answer: 21.
common_errors: Not understanding the layout (where to write the quotient digits)
Dividing 4 by 84 instead of 84 by 4

levels.label: developing
levels.description: Dividing three- and four-digit numbers by a one-digit divisor, including cases with remainders and zeros in the quotient.
levels.example_task: Use short division: 4,218 ÷ 6.
levels.example_response: 4 ÷ 6 = 0 remainder 4 (carry 4 to make 42). 42 ÷ 6 = 7. 1 ÷ 6 = 0 remainder 1 (carry 1 to make 18). 18 ÷ 6 = 3. Answer: 703.
common_errors: Omitting the zero in the quotient (writing 73 instead of 703)
Forgetting to carry the remainder to the next column

levels.label: expected
levels.description: Completing short division for any four-digit ÷ one-digit, interpreting remainders as whole numbers, fractions or decimals depending on context.
levels.example_task: 435 children are put into teams of 8. How many full teams? How many children left over? Express the answer as a decimal.
levels.example_response: 435 ÷ 8 = 54 remainder 3. So 54 full teams with 3 children left over. As a decimal: 54.375 (continue dividing: 30 ÷ 8 = 3 r6, 60 ÷ 8 = 7 r4, 40 ÷ 8 = 5).
common_errors: Writing '54 r3' without interpreting what the remainder means in context
Not knowing how to continue short division past the decimal point

levels.label: entry
levels.description: Adding fractions with the same denominator and with related denominators where one is a multiple of the other.
levels.example_task: Work out 1/4 + 3/8.
levels.example_response: Convert 1/4 to 2/8. Then 2/8 + 3/8 = 5/8.
common_errors: Adding numerators and denominators: 1/4 + 3/8 = 4/12
Not converting to a common denominator first

levels.label: developing
levels.description: Adding and subtracting fractions where neither denominator is a multiple of the other, finding a common denominator using LCM.
levels.example_task: Work out 2/3 + 1/4.
common_errors: Using 3 × 4 = 12 as the common denominator but only converting one fraction
Adding numerators and denominators: 2/3 + 1/4 = 3/7

levels.label: expected
levels.description: Adding and subtracting fractions with any denominators, simplifying results and converting improper fractions to mixed numbers.
levels.example_task: Work out 5/6 + 3/4. Give your answer as a mixed number in its simplest form.
common_errors: Not simplifying the answer (leaving as 19/12 when asked for a mixed number)
Converting incorrectly: writing 19/12 as 1 9/12 instead of 1 7/12

levels.label: entry
levels.description: Identifying improper fractions and mixed numbers on a number line, understanding that 5/4 means 'more than one whole'.
levels.example_task: Place 7/4 on the number line. Is it more or less than 2?
levels.example_response: 7/4 = 1 3/4. It is less than 2. [Places it between 1 and 2, three-quarters of the way along]
common_errors: Placing 7/4 between 0 and 1 (not understanding it is greater than 1)
Saying 7/4 = 7.4 (misreading the fraction as a decimal)

levels.label: developing
levels.description: Converting between improper fractions and mixed numbers using division.
levels.example_task: Convert 17/5 to a mixed number. Convert 3 2/7 to an improper fraction.
common_errors: Writing 17/5 = 3 remainder 2 but not forming the fraction (leaving as '3 r 2')
Computing 3 × 7 = 21 but forgetting to add the numerator (writing 21/7 instead of 23/7)

levels.label: expected
levels.description: Converting fluently in both directions and using the appropriate form for addition, subtraction and comparison.
levels.example_task: Which is larger, 2 3/5 or 11/4? Show your working.
common_errors: Comparing 13/5 and 11/4 by comparing numerators only (13 > 11 so 13/5 must be larger)
Not finding a common denominator before comparing

levels.label: entry
levels.description: Shading a hundredths grid to show common percentages and connecting to the fraction form.
levels.example_task: Shade 50% of the hundredths grid. What fraction is this?
levels.example_response: 50 out of 100 squares shaded. 50% = 50/100 = 1/2.
common_errors: Shading 50 squares but not recognising this as 1/2
Thinking 50% means 50 (confusing percentage with a whole number)

levels.label: developing
levels.description: Converting between percentages, fractions and decimals for common benchmarks: 50%, 25%, 10%, 1%, 20%, 75%.
levels.example_task: Write 25% as a fraction and a decimal. Write 0.1 as a percentage.
common_errors: Writing 25% = 0.25 but 25% = 25/10 (wrong denominator)
Writing 0.1 = 1% (dividing by 10 instead of multiplying by 100)

levels.label: expected
levels.description: Converting any percentage to a fraction and decimal, and finding a percentage of a quantity using known equivalences.
levels.example_task: Find 15% of £80. Show your method.
common_errors: Computing 15 × 80 = 1,200 and not dividing by 100 (getting £1,200 instead of £12)
Not building up from known percentages (10%, 5%, 1%)

levels.label: entry
levels.description: Identifying acute, right and obtuse angles by sight, and estimating their size before measuring.
levels.example_task: Is this angle acute, right or obtuse? Estimate its size. [Shows a 65° angle]
levels.example_response: It is acute (less than 90°). I estimate about 60°.
common_errors: Calling an acute angle obtuse or vice versa
Estimating wildly (saying 30° for a 65° angle)

levels.label: developing
levels.description: Measuring angles to the nearest degree using a protractor, correctly choosing the inner or outer scale.
levels.example_task: Measure this angle using a protractor. [Shows a 125° angle]
levels.example_response: 125°. I placed the centre on the vertex, aligned the baseline with one arm, and read 125° from the correct scale (the one starting at 0 on the baseline).
common_errors: Reading 55° instead of 125° (using the wrong scale on the protractor)
Not placing the centre of the protractor on the vertex

levels.label: expected
levels.description: Measuring and drawing angles accurately, classifying angles (acute, right, obtuse, straight, reflex), and estimating before measuring to check reasonableness.
levels.example_task: Draw an angle of 137°. What type of angle is it?
levels.example_response: [Draws 137° accurately with a protractor] It is an obtuse angle because it is between 90° and 180°.
common_errors: Drawing 43° instead of 137° (using the wrong scale)
Not estimating first — if an angle looks obtuse but the reading says 43°, the wrong scale was used

levels.label: entry
levels.description: Using the fact that angles on a straight line sum to 180° to find a missing angle in a two-angle configuration.
levels.example_task: Two angles sit on a straight line. One is 65°. What is the other?
common_errors: Using 360° instead of 180° (confusing straight line with full turn)
Subtracting from 90° instead of 180°

levels.label: developing
levels.description: Using angles at a point (360°) and angles in a triangle (180°) to find missing angles.
levels.example_task: A triangle has angles of 40° and 75°. What is the third angle?
common_errors: Using 360° instead of 180° for the triangle angle sum
Making an arithmetic error in the subtraction (180 – 115 = 75 instead of 65)

levels.label: expected
levels.description: Combining two or more angle facts in a multi-step calculation, stating which fact is used at each step.
levels.example_task: Angle ABC on a straight line is 130°. Triangle BCD has angle BCD = 50°. Find angle BDC. State the angle facts you use.
levels.example_response: Angle DBC = 180° – 130° = 50° (angles on a straight line). Angle BDC = 180° – 50° – 50° = 80° (angles in a triangle sum to 180°).
common_errors: Not stating which angle fact is used at each step
Applying the wrong fact to the wrong configuration

levels.label: entry
levels.description: Reading and writing numbers with one decimal place in a measurement context (e.g. 3.7 m), identifying the value of the tenths digit.
levels.example_task: A rope is 4.6 m long. What does the 6 represent?
levels.example_response: The 6 represents 6 tenths of a metre, which is 60 cm.
common_errors: Saying the 6 represents 6 metres or 6 cm
Not connecting tenths of a metre to centimetres

levels.label: developing
levels.description: Reading, writing and ordering numbers with up to three decimal places, identifying the value of each digit.
levels.example_task: Order these: 0.345, 0.35, 0.4, 0.305. What is the value of the 5 in 0.345?
levels.example_response: Order: 0.305, 0.345, 0.35, 0.4. The 5 in 0.345 is worth 5 thousandths (0.005).
common_errors: Ordering as 0.305, 0.35, 0.345, 0.4 (comparing 35 and 345 as whole numbers)
Saying the 5 is worth 5 hundredths instead of 5 thousandths

levels.label: expected
levels.description: Comparing and ordering decimals with different numbers of decimal places, connecting to fractions, and placing them on a number line.
levels.example_task: Place 0.075, 0.7 and 0.507 on a number line from 0 to 1. Write 0.075 as a fraction.
levels.example_response: Order: 0.075, 0.507, 0.7. 0.075 = 75/1000 = 3/40. [Places correctly on line with 0.075 near 0, 0.507 just past halfway, 0.7 at seven-tenths]
common_errors: Placing 0.075 after 0.507 because 75 > 50
Writing 0.075 as 75/100 instead of 75/1000

levels.label: entry
levels.description: Building cuboids from 1 cm³ cubes and counting the total to find volume.
levels.example_task: Build a cuboid that is 3 cubes long, 2 cubes wide and 2 cubes tall. How many cubes did you use?
levels.example_response: 12 cubes. The volume is 12 cm³.
common_errors: Counting only the visible cubes and not the hidden ones inside
Not understanding that volume counts the 3-D space, not just the outside

levels.label: developing
levels.description: Using the formula V = l × w × h to calculate volume of cuboids, and distinguishing volume from area.
levels.example_task: A box is 5 cm long, 4 cm wide and 3 cm tall. What is its volume?
common_errors: Computing 5 × 4 = 20 and stopping (finding area of the base, not volume)
Writing the answer as 60 cm² instead of 60 cm³

levels.label: expected
levels.description: Calculating volume of cuboids in different units, estimating volumes, and finding a missing dimension given the volume.
levels.example_task: A cuboid has volume 120 cm³. Its length is 10 cm and width is 4 cm. What is its height?
common_errors: Not rearranging the formula (guessing instead of dividing)
Dividing by only one dimension instead of the product of the other two

levels.label: entry
levels.description: Reflecting a simple shape in a vertical or horizontal mirror line on squared paper by counting squares from key vertices to the line.
levels.example_task: Reflect this triangle in the vertical mirror line. The top vertex is 2 squares from the line.
levels.example_response: [Draws the reflected triangle with the top vertex 2 squares on the other side of the line]
common_errors: Counting along the mirror line instead of perpendicular to it
Reflecting only some of the vertices and distorting the shape

levels.label: developing
levels.description: Translating shapes on a coordinate grid by moving every vertex the same amount in the same direction.
levels.example_task: Translate the rectangle 3 right and 2 down. The corner at (1, 5) moves to where?
levels.example_response: (1+3, 5–2) = (4, 3). [All other vertices also shift 3 right and 2 down]
common_errors: Moving different vertices by different amounts
Moving 3 up instead of 3 right (confusing horizontal and vertical)

levels.label: expected
levels.description: Reflecting shapes in the x-axis and y-axis on a four-quadrant grid and describing the effect on coordinates.
levels.example_task: Reflect point (3, –2) in the y-axis. What are the new coordinates?
levels.example_response: (–3, –2). Reflecting in the y-axis changes the sign of the x-coordinate but keeps the y-coordinate the same.
common_errors: Changing the y-coordinate instead of the x-coordinate: (3, 2) instead of (–3, –2)
Changing both coordinates: (–3, 2)

levels.label: entry
levels.description: Adding and subtracting four-digit numbers using formal columnar methods with exchanges, consolidating Year 4 fluency.
levels.example_task: Work out 5,607 – 2,839 using column subtraction.
levels.example_response: 5,607 – 2,839 = 2,768. Cascading exchange needed: borrow from the hundreds through the tens to the ones.
common_errors: Cascading exchange through the 0 in the tens column causes the most errors
Subtracting the smaller digit from the larger regardless of position

levels.label: developing
levels.description: Adding and subtracting numbers with more than four digits using formal methods and selecting mental methods when appropriate.
levels.example_task: Work out 34,567 + 28,945. Would you use a mental method for 4,998 + 3,457?
common_errors: Using the column method for everything, even when a mental method is more efficient
Carrying errors when multiple columns require exchanges

levels.label: expected
levels.description: Fluently adding and subtracting any whole numbers using formal or mental methods, with estimation to check, in multi-step problem contexts.
levels.example_task: A school raised £12,450 in the first term and £9,876 in the second term. They spent £15,320 on equipment. How much is left?
common_errors: Computing one step correctly but making an error in the second step
Not estimating to check: 12,000 + 10,000 – 15,000 ≈ 7,000 confirms the answer

levels.label: entry
levels.description: Reading values from a line graph where the scale goes up in ones and all data points are at labelled positions.
levels.example_task: This line graph shows the temperature each hour. What was the temperature at 2 pm?
levels.example_response: 15°C. [Reads directly from the plotted point at 2 pm]
common_errors: Reading the wrong axis (giving the time when asked for temperature)
Reading one gridline above or below the correct value

levels.label: developing
levels.description: Reading line graphs with non-unit scales (intervals of 2, 5, 10, 25) and interpolating between plotted points; reading timetables.
levels.example_task: The y-axis goes up in 5s. The line passes halfway between 15 and 20 at 11 am. What is the value? A bus leaves at 09:15 and arrives at 10:02. How long is the journey?
levels.example_response: 17.5°C (halfway between 15 and 20). Journey time: 47 minutes (15 min to 09:30, 30 min to 10:00, 2 min to 10:02).
common_errors: Reading 17 or 18 instead of 17.5 because the point is between gridlines
Computing journey time as 10:02 – 9:15 = 0:87 = 87 minutes (subtracting digits without converting)

levels.label: expected
levels.description: Interpreting line graphs to describe trends, solve comparison and difference problems, and critically evaluate whether the graph is appropriate for the data.
levels.example_task: This line graph shows plant heights over 6 weeks. Between which two weeks did the plant grow the most? Is a line graph a good choice for this data? Why?
levels.example_response: The plant grew the most between weeks 2 and 3 — the line is steepest there (grew 4 cm). A line graph is a good choice because the data is continuous over time and we can interpolate between measurements.
common_errors: Identifying the week with the tallest measurement rather than the steepest growth
Not understanding when a line graph is appropriate versus a bar chart
